articles.title: Declaring ecocide as crime against humanity
articles.author: Avay Shukla
articles.summary: The Paris Accord redline of 1.5°C temperature increase has been breached, CO2 levels have gone up by 125% above pre-industrial levels and at 425 ppm are approaching the survival limit of 450 ppm. 10 million hectares of forest are felled every year globally. 30% of the forests in the Amazon basin have already been lost to mining and logging. Ecuador has finalised plans to auction 3 million ha of the Amazon forests for mining. Indonesia is in the process of implementing the largest deforestation project in the world: 30,689 sq km of the third largest rain forest is being cleared to grow sugarcane.

articles.title: Near-record to record-setting warmth continued in Central Florida
articles.author: David Heckard
articles.summary: There was near-record to record-setting warmth on Saturday and more warmth is ahead for Sunday. Monday's highs will be in the upper 90s. Tuesday's hottest day may be Tuesday, with dry conditions continuing. Thursday's temperatures will fall into the upper 80s and low 90s due to a cold front.

articles.title: Home building rush balances price tags with power bills
articles.author: Sebastian Tan
articles.summary: As winter nears, flicking on of gas heaters and firing up of ovens is becoming more common in Australian homes as the cold weather nears. It's also getting colder outside. It is getting colder in Australia as winter approaches, so people are using ovens more often.

articles.title: Home building rush balances price tags with power bills
articles.author: Sebastian Tan
articles.summary: As winter nears, flicking on of gas heaters and firing up of ovens is becoming more common in Australian homes as the cold weather nears. It's also getting colder outside. It is getting colder in Australia as winter approaches, so people are using ovens more often.

articles.title: ICE FREE
articles.author: Administrator
articles.summary: Send this to someone worried about the Climate Change Scam Hoax and the end of Earth. It is not easy nor inexpensive to provide readers of this site with the best unbiased information available and a forum where it can be discussed openly. I need your help and support to keep it alive. Please consider contributing an amount commensurate to the value that you receive from this site and the community.

articles.title: Weird weather leaves people wondering whether to switch on a fan or a heater
articles.summary: Bala, Gwynedd, has been experiencing ground frosts before seeing the mercury soar during the day. In contrast, residents in Aberdaron, on the Llŷn Peninsula, work up to a relatively balmy 11C. Big temperature swings have been a recurring theme in recent days in Bala. Bigger differences have been recorded in Scotland.

articles.title: Why is Scotland so warm, and why hasn't it rained in so long?
articles.author: Fiona Brown
articles.summary: The recent sunny spells in Glasgow and elsewhere in Scotland are caused by a blocking high pressure system. Edward Graham, a lecturer at the University of the Highlands and Islands, explains that statistics regarding dryness are provisional until the month is over. The driest part of the year is March, April, May and June. The sunniest month is May in the west of Scotland.

articles.title: Opinion: The mystery of Anchorage's missing songbirds
articles.author: Bill Sherwonit
articles.summary: Anchorage's avian population has been on the decline this winter. Bird watchers are puzzled by the lack of songbirds. Bird flu is unlikely to be a cause of the decline. Starlings might be more of a factor than avian flu.

articles.title: Co-op prioritises corporate greed over animal welfare, says Chris Packham
articles.author: Rosie Shead
articles.summary: Chickens are taking on too much weight too quickly for their skeleton to cope with it. They end up scrabbling around in their own excrement, which is acrid and burns their skin off. They also have deformities and muscular problems in the chickens.

articles.title: Perils of the Sinking Shores
articles.author: Krishna Gupta
articles.summary: Coastal areas are vulnerable to rising sea levels, higher intensity and increased moisture-carrying capacity of storms, scarcity of freshwater, ingress of salty sea water into agricultural lands, and the rising carbon dioxide in ocean water. IPCC estimated that ocean levels will rise between 17 cm and 38 cm by 2050, and between 26 cm and 82 cm by the year 2100.

articles.title: AZ: GREER FIRE GROWS TO MORE THAN 15K ACRES
articles.summary: The Greer Fire in eastern Arizona is continuing to grow. It's impacting people in the Eagar and Springerville areas. It is burning near the town of Eagar, Arizona, and it's affecting people in Springerville, Arizona as well.

articles.title: "ReString Appalachia" spreading through areas hit by 2024 hurricanes
articles.author: CBS News
articles.summary: Some in western North Carolina feel the 2024 hurricane season will be worse than the 2025 hurricane season. It's because of the upcoming hurricane season, which is around the corner, and 2025 is the next hurricane season in North Carolina's calendar year. It will be in 2024.

articles.title: Antarctica Glacier Caught Stealing From Its Neighbor, ‘Ice Piracy' Is Not Good for Sea Levels
articles.summary: Kohler East Glacier gained immense speed within 17 years, while the Kohler West Glacier slowed down. The research team monitored the changes that would impact the speed of ice flow and would lead to a rise in sea levels. The data on sea level rise showed that global sea levels increased by more than 10cm in the last ten years.

articles.title: Humanity faced a massive famine in 2024 — online.ua
articles.summary: In 2024, record levels of global hunger were recorded in various corners of the planet Earth. For the first time since monitoring began, 1.9 million people faced critical food shortages. 22.6% of the population in regions where food shortages are most acute are facing hunger at least at crisis level. Last year, more than 295 million people in 53 countries and territories faced these problems.

articles.title: NASA-led Analysis Reveals Sudden Change in Global Sea Level Last Year, Puzzles Scientists
articles.author: Somdatta Maity
articles.summary: Global sea levels rose by 0.23 inches in 2024. This is more than the expected rise of 0.17 inches. Experts believe climate change is the main reason behind the rise in sea levels. NASA started keeping records of global sea levels in 1993. Since then, sea levels have risen by around four inches.

articles.title: Sagarmatha Sambaad: Mountain region bearing brunt of climate change
articles.summary: Stakeholders have expressed worry over climate change posing severe threats to mountain region in a session on 'Risk and assessment of mountain region' organized as part of Sagarmatha Sambaad today. Director of Chinese Academy of Sciences, China, Dr Tao Wang, opined that mountain region have been affected most due to temperature rising globally. Academic Associate at the University of Zurich, Switzerland, Dr Simon Allen, stressed the need to develop local-level capacity to face climate change impacts.

articles.title: Acharya Prashant Discusses 'Operation 2030' and the Path to Sustainable Success at Book Launch
articles.author: ANI
articles.summary: The UNFCCC has served as the foundation for global climate negotiations, leading to the Kyoto Protocol in 1997 and the Paris Agreement in 2015. The global temperature rise has already exceeded 1.5°C, with some evidence suggesting it has reached 1.7°C as of 2025. The Industrial Revolution, which began around 1750, marked a turning point in this conquest.

articles.title: How ISRO's EOS-09 satellite will revolutionize disaster response, security surveillance
articles.summary: The C-band SAR also bolsters national development by assisting agriculture, forestry, hydrology, and urban planning. It can monitor illegal maritime activity at sea, track oil spills, or pinpoint vessels along India's 7,500km coastline. It will also classify terrain, vegetation, and man-made structures.

articles.title: Arctic Air Reaches Further South Than Ever Before
articles.author: Nelleke van Niekerk
articles.summary: This past winter, millions were caught off guard as frigid air typically trapped near the North Pole surged across continents. For lifelong residents in southern towns, the icy invasion felt surreal and alarming. In this article, we'll unravel the story behind one of the most astonishing and unsettling weather phenomena of our time.

articles.title: As climate hazards worsen, Trump moves to weaken FEMA and shift disaster response onto states
articles.author: Class
articles.summary: The recent firing of the head of the Federal Emergency Management Agency is the latest blow for the agency. The dismissal of acting director Cameron Hamilton on May 8 adds to ongoing layoffs, budget cuts, grant cancellations and leadership changes at FEMA. The agency could run out of money as soon as July, just in time for the danger season.

articles.title: Melting Arctic Ice Driving Intense Monsoon Rains Over South Asia, IITM Study Finds
articles.author: Rahul Dolare
articles.summary: A new study from the Indian Institute of Tropical Meteorology (IITM), Pune, under the Ministry of Earth Sciences, has found a link between the melting of Arctic sea ice and increasingly intense monsoon rainfall across South Asia. The research shows that Arctic climate change is reshaping weather systems thousands of kilometers away.

articles.title: The New Scientist Is Flat Wrong – We Live in a Golden Age Thanks to a Warmer Climate
articles.author: Anthony Watts
articles.summary: In a recent article in The New Scientist, James Dinneen claims that climate change is already making people's lives worse due to increased food prices, disrupted sleep, and longer commute times. This narrative is misleading, at best, and outright false in many instances. Data suggests that despite localized weather disruptions, global crop yields are at record highs, overall mortality rates from climate-related events have decreased, and adaptive technologies have mitigated potential risks.

articles.title: Funeral for a narrative
articles.author: Duggan Flanakin
articles.summary: This week's column focuses on the theme of truths inconvenient for the climate cult. There is a new scientific study that erodes the arguments in favor of the theory of manmade global warming. Norweigan ferry operator announced the world's first passenger ferry powered by hydrogen fuel in 2023.

articles.title: The Dying Green Narrative Lies Bleeding in the Hands of Activists, Cult Members, and Their Corporatist Enablers
articles.author: Duggan Flanakin
articles.summary: This week's CFACT column focuses on the global warming argument. The narrative behind it is dying. New scientific study disproves the arguments in favor of the theory of manmade global warming. NOAA retires its 'billion-dollar disaster' boondoggle. A German chemical plant is trucking hydrogen gas to Norway.

articles.title: Empowering Women Leaders in Iraq: FAO and SIDA Advance Climate Resilience through CWW Intensive Training in Erbil
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The six-day Intensive Training of Trainers (TOT) session in Erbil is a pivotal advancement in the Climate Wise Women initiative. It is aimed at empowering rural Iraqi women as leaders of climate action and resilience in their communities. The CWW initiative in Iraq exemplifies a transformative model where local leadership is fused with scientific knowledge to catalyze systemic change.

articles.title: Co-Op prioritises corporate greed over animal welfare
articles.author: Rosie Shead
articles.summary: Chickens are taking on too much weight too quickly for their skeleton to cope with it. They end up scrabbling around in their own excrement, which is acrid and burns their skin off. They also see deformities and muscular problems in the chickens.

articles.title: M6.0 earthquake hits central Peru at intermediate depth
articles.author: Teo Blašković
articles.summary: 570 000 people in the affected area felt light shaking. USGS issues a Green alert for shaking-related fatalities and economic losses. The region is connected to the coastal Pan-American Highway corridor via major inland roads, such as PE-30A. The predominant vulnerable building types are mud wall and reinforced/confined masonry construction.

articles.title: Scientists predict when life on earth will come to an end, read details to know more
articles.author: Kirti
articles.summary: Scientists at Toho University in Tokyo, Japan, applied NASA planetary modeling to perform 400,000 simulations and forecast the destiny of Earth's atmosphere. In approximately one billion years, the Earth's environment will become rapidly deoxygenated, and life will find it challenging to survive.

articles.title: Farmers warn of soaring food prices as rare event wipes out crops across vast area: 'Raising costs and lowering incomes'
articles.author: Cody Januszko
articles.summary: Almost half of Turkey's provinces were hit by an agricultural freeze in mid-April. The freeze from April 10-12 damaged many crops across 36 of its 81 provinces. The resulting loss of tea, fruits, vegetables, and nuts will drive food prices up and hurt farmers financially. Climate change is raising costs and lowering incomes for farmers.

articles.title: Global Warming, Scorching Nights, Urbanisation Steal 44 Hours Of Rest Each Year: Study
articles.author: Surabhi Gupta
articles.summary: Temperatures are rising due to climate change and urbanization. People lose an average of 44 hours of sleep every year due to high temperatures. The problem is worse in high-income countries, where people are more exposed to urban heat and often experience greater mental stress and physical fatigue.

articles.title: Proposed Bill 5 threatens Ontario wildlife and ecosystems
articles.author: Cathie Coward/The
articles.summary: Ryan Norris and Quinn Webber are professors at the University of Guelph. They write that under Bill 5, the habitats of migratory birds will no longer be protected under the Magnuson-Migratory Species Act. They also write that tundra swans made a stop in Burlington Bay.

articles.title: Trump wants to slash funding for climate adaptation—here's what we're going to lose because of it
articles.author: Fast Company
articles.summary: Warming temperatures, wildfires and flash floods are increasingly affecting lives across the United States. The U.S. government is planning to ramp up fossil fuel use. The risks of these events are likely to become more frequent and dangerous.    .   and

articles.title: Ice theft in Antarctica: A glacier stealing ice from its neighbour, raising sea levels, as well as concerns
articles.author: TOI Science Desk
articles.summary: Kohler East Glacier redirected some of the flow from Kohler West Glacier in order to steal ice from its neighbour. Scientists call it 'ice piracy' and it could affect millions of people living along the coasts. The Dotson and Crosson ice shelves fed by these glaciers are already thinning and retreating.

articles.title: Scientists reveal the US states where Americans are aging faster for a surprising reason
articles.author: Chris Melore
articles.summary: In recent years, the US has seen hundreds of thousands of residents relocate to Texas, Florida and North Carolina. A new study found that prolonged exposure to high temperatures can speed up biological aging. Older adults are at the greatest risk from long-term heat exposure, with temperatures in the 80s leading to accelerated aging.

articles.title: Public Forum: NOAA kept us safe
articles.author: Burns
articles.summary: The National Weather Service and the National Hurricane Center are critical for protecting life and property. Recent budget cuts to the NOAA have raised concerns about the accuracy and timeliness of forecasts, as the agency has experienced major staffing reductions due to federal budget cuts. Greenville has benefitted from their close attention to storm and hurricane forecasting.

articles.title: Trump wants to slash funding for climate adaptation—here's what we're going to lose because of it
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: The White House proposes to eliminate funding for climate adaptation science in the next federal budget. U.S. Geological Survey has been funding regional Climate Adaptation Science Centers since 2011. The centers help states and tribes build resilience to climate change. They help communities prepare for wildfires, protect shorelines and save salmon.

articles.title: A wakeup call
articles.author: Agency
articles.summary: India is facing increasingly harsh and prolonged summer seasons due to global warming. The rise in greenhouse gas emissions, rampant deforestation, and unplanned urbanisation have all contributed to a dangerous imbalance in nature's rhythm. India must prioritise both short-term relief measures and long-term sustainability efforts.

articles.title: Italy launches €4 million climate resilience initiative for Sindh
articles.author: Shoaib Nizami
articles.summary: Italian humanitarian organization CESVI has launched a €4 million project to strengthen the climate resilience of vulnerable communities in Sindh. The initiative is funded by the Italian Agency for Development Cooperation (AICS). The project seeks to enhance resilience in communities at risk from climate impacts through anticipatory action.

articles.title: Climate Change Threat To Education In Nigeria
articles.author: Leadership News
articles.summary: Governing board member of the North East Development Commission, Sam Onuigbo, has said climate change poses significant threats to education in the country. He delivered a paper at the Conference of Deans of Education Nigerian Universities 2025 Annual Conference and General Meeting at Michael Okpara University of Agriculture, Umudike.

articles.title: Bushfire Alert: Planned Burn on Arnhem Hwy, Marrakai
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Bushfires NT volunteer brigades will be conducting road verge burning as part of the annual mitigation program. There is a planned burn currently underway on Road Verge, Arnhem Highway, Adelaide River to Marrakai Access Road, Morocco. Smoke from the fire may affect visibility and active fire may occur close to the roadside.

articles.title: Climate Changes, We Don't
articles.summary: More than 1,000 people have been laid off at NOAA, including from the National Weather Service. According to NOAA, 2024 was the warmest on record since accurate records started being kept around 1850. Global temperatures exceeded 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels for the first time. Extreme weather events are becoming an annual event in the U.S. and in the rest of the world.

articles.title: Real Ice Experiments with Polar Geoengineering to Refreeze Melting Arctic Sea Ice
articles.author: Rachel Feltman
articles.summary: Climate change is causing Arctic sea ice to melt. Alec Luhn is taking Scientific American's Science Quickly team on a trip to the Arctic. It's been the warmest winter in 75 years, and the temperature at the North Pole briefly went above freezing.

articles.title: Mosquito season is here early: What to know about protecting your family from disease
articles.author: ABC7
articles.summary: With longer, hotter summers and shifting weather, there will be longer and hotter summers in the future, according to the scientists.   Â     “Shifting weather’s” cause is due to longer and warmer summers.

articles.title: Rising heat
articles.author: Javed Younas
articles.summary: Temperatures will remain 4°C to 7°C above normal in many regions of Pakistan, with parts of southern Punjab and Sindh already experiencing highs above 45°C. In Punjab, the Provincial Disaster Management Authority has ramped up emergency measures, directing hospitals to set up dedicated heatwave counters and stock lifesaving medicines. In rural areas, the state presence remains worryingly thin.

articles.title: New update on ‘Bird wing' solar eruption that could hit Earth
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: A major solar eruption is set to possibly impact the Earth tomorrow. The eruption is caused by a superheated plasma surging across the Sun's surface. It's being called the "bird-wing" event. It comes as a direct warning from astronomers.

articles.title: Invisible impacts: Climate change and mental health
articles.summary: The climate crisis is not just an environmental or economic challenge but also a mental health crisis. Global studies link extreme weather events to spikes in depression, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), and suicide rates. Solastalgia, a term coined by philosopher Glenn Albrecht to describe distress caused by environmental change in one's home environment, resonates deeply in climate-affected communities.

articles.title: Virus carried to UK by mosquitoes ‘has killed up to 40% of local blackbirds'
articles.author: Metro UK
articles.summary: climate change has fuelled the spread of diseases like dioxin and euthenasexualisease, according to the WHO.    for the WHO's report on dioxins in the environment.  For more information, go to: http://www.cdoj.org/.

articles.title: Rising heat
articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: Temperatures are rising mercilessly across Pakistan due to climate change. The country will have to endure recurring cycles of deadly heat, which will likely intensify. The toll on lives and livelihoods grows heavier each year, while our preparedness lags dangerously behind.

articles.title: America's Impact on the Global Thermostat
articles.author: Dissident Voice
articles.summary: The Trump administration is pushing for 100% fossil fuels and as much coal burning as possible. U.S. greenhouse gas emissions levels are estimated to rise up to 36 percent higher than current policy by 2035 under the Trump administration. The administration considers climate change an expensive hoax.

articles.title: Italy launches $4.4m climate resilience project for rural Sindh
articles.author: Mehtab Haider
articles.summary: Italy signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) with various organisations to implement a 36-month, $4.4 million project aimed at strengthening vulnerable communities facing climate-related risks in rural Sindh. The initiative is funded by the Italian Agency for Development Cooperation and aims to build resilience among communities exposed to climate shocks.

articles.title: Skagit County protected 460 acres of farmland in 2024
articles.author: Cameron Martinez
articles.summary: The Skagit County Farmland Legacy Program protected 460 acres of farmland from development in 2024. The properties were near Burlington, Conway, Mount Vernon and Sedro-Woolley. They ranged in size from 8 1/2 acres to 267 acres.

articles.title: The Free Market has made ovens, not houses
articles.author: Martyn Bradbury
articles.summary: Auckland's emergency teams are preparing for climate change. Aidan Milner is a hazard and warning adviser at Auckland Emergency Management. He is part of a national heat reference group including scientists, the Ministry of Health and emergency managers. Some terraced houses in Auckland are overheating due to poor design and lack of insulation.

articles.title: UN chief raises international alarm over melting of Himalayan glaciers in Nepal
articles.author: Jurist
articles.summary: Antonio Guterres sent a video message to the Nepalese government on Friday, warning that the Himalayan glaciers are rapidly melting and urging immediate action. Nepal produces a negligible amount of emissions in comparison to other countries, but they are still emitting a lot.

articles.title: Antarctic and Arctic Ice Trends Defy Climate Models And Dire Predictions
articles.author: Principia Scientific
articles.summary: The important mainland ice of Antarctica is disappearing at an increasing rate, according to the Helmholtz Association's climate website 'Climate Facts' under Antarctica. The website states that Antarctica's ice is decreasing at a faster rate than the rest of the world's ice sheets.

articles.title: Sac State professor hosts screening of climate documentary on Greenland ice melt
articles.author: Sacramento Bee
articles.summary: The educational documentary discusses how climate change has affected the Earth's temperature in a 60-minute film. It is based on a documentary produced by the BBC. It's about the effects of climate change on Earth's temperatures. It discusses how it affects the atmosphere.

articles.title: New Study Reveals Recent Ice Gains in Antarctica, But Long-Term Melting Continues
articles.author: NDTV
articles.summary: A study led by Tongji University using NASA's GRACE satellites has observed recent ice gains in Antarctica from 2021 to 2023 mainly due to unusual precipitation. However, the long-term ice gain is due to longer-term changes in the weather, such as snowfall.

articles.title: US East Coast faces rising seas as crucial Atlantic current slows
articles.author: New Scientist
articles.summary: The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) is weakening. This is boosting the sea level along the New England coast on top of sea level rise from melting ice, adding to flooding there.       .

articles.title: 'Unprecedented and alarming': Bird flu has morphed to wipe out seals
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Australia is surrounded by the deadly H5N1 strain of bird flu. Sea animals and birds are bringing the virus closer to the shores of the country. It is morphing as it gets closer to Australia's shores and is getting more lethal.

articles.title: NASA Satellite Detects Tree Leaf Changes as Early Volcano Eruption Warning Signal
articles.author: NDTV
articles.summary: NASA and Smithsonian scientists find that greener trees seen in satellite images may warn of upcoming volcanic eruptions. The change is linked to rising carbon dioxide emissions from magma, which may be caused by volcanic activity, which is causing the greening of the trees.

articles.title: Severe thunderstorm warning issued in Muskoka.
articles.author: CTV
articles.summary: Environment and Climate Change Canada is concerned about climate change. It's concerned about the effects of climate change on the environment and climate change change on people's lives. Its main focus is on people and their livelihoods. It is also concerned about people's well-being.
